_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: State of Alaska CAA Title V Operating Permit

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Description of stationary source and regulated substances handled:
The Lisburne Production Center (LPC) is located in the East Operating Area (EOA) of Prudhoe Bay. LPC processes crude oil production fluids received from various crude oil accumulations (collectively known as the Greater Pt. McIntyre area or GPMA) located on the North Slope of Alaska, including (but not limited to) Lisburne, Point McIntyre, Niakuk, West Beach State, and North Prudhoe Bay State. Production fluids consist mainly of crude oil, hydrocarbon gas, and water.
Crude oil is processed to remove hydrocarbon gas and water in order to meet specific crude oil sales specifications. Sales oil then enters the Trans-Alaska Pipeline. Hydrocarbon gas is dehydrated, stripped of butane and heavier hydrocarbons that may be present, and compressed for re-injection into the reservoirs or used as fuel. Water is processed to remove entrained crude oil before injection into disposal or injector wells.

LPC contains a propane refrigeration system as well as a NGL/MI processing system. The NGLs and MI consist of a mixture containing Methane, Ethane, Propane, Butane, Iso-Butane, Pentane, and Iso-Pentane. All other hydrocarbons at LPC are considered naturally occuring hydrocarbons mixtures and are not subject to 40 CFR §68.3.

Dry Gas Refrigeration System:
LPC utilizes propane in a dry gas refrigeration system. Liquid propane is generally prepared on site at LPC and added to the surge drum as needed. The propane refrigeration system is a closed circulating loop. Therefore assuming high liquid level in all vessels simultaneously was not considered credible. To be conservative the total propane quantify is based off of high liquid level in the Surge Drum and normal operating levels in all other equipment as follows:
-	The propane accumulator/surge drum 42-1242 provides liquid propane storage. The surge drum has a maximum liquid volume of approximately 10,500 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 44,000 lbs.
-	The interstage flash dr

um 42-1243 and low stage suction drum 42-1244 facilitate compression of propane refrigerant in multiple stages, which improves overall system efficiency. 
o	At normal operating level, the 42-1243 interstage flash drum contains approximately 1,050 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 4,500 lbs.
o	At normal operating level, the 42-1244 low stage suction drum contains approximately 0 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 0 lbs.
-	The De-prop Proane Chillers 42-1359 and 42-1314 provide for heat exchange between incoming process natural gas and propane refrigerant. 
o	At normal operating level, the De-prop Proane Chiller 42-1359 contains 7,000 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 30,000 lbs. 
o	At normal operating level, the De-prop Proane Chiller 42-1314 contains 7,900 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 33,500 lbs. 
Total maximum propane inventory onsite is approximately 26,500 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 112,000 lbs.

Catastrophic loss of inventory of the 42-1242 Surge Drum is the basis for the Worst Case Scenario calculations as it can have up to 44,000 lbs, based on the high level alarm, during times when the system is down.  The model used was a RMP*Comp. 

NGL/MI Storage and Handling:
Dehydrated gas is routed to low-temperature processing where it is chilled using the propane refrigeration process to extract natural gas liquids (NGL) for use as Miscible Injectant (MI). The mixed NGL, comprised primarily of liquid hydrocarbons in the propane (C3) through pentane (C5) range, is a regulated flammable substance. The quantity of NGL/MI in process/storage at the LPC consists of the following equipment and approximate inventories:
-	The 42-1252 Depropanizer Feed Flash Drum has a design liquid volume of 7,300 gallons of mixed NGL/MI @ 3.26 lbs/ gal and 75% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 18,000 lbs.
-	The 42-1344 Depropanizer Feed/Liquid Exchanger with NGL/MI present on the shell side of the exchanger has an available shell side volume of 500 gallons NGL/MI @ 3.26 lbs/gal and 75% by weight Part 68 subject compon

ents (C1-C5) = 1,300 lbs.
-	The 42-1253 Depropanizer Economizer Drum has a design liquid volume of 14,500 gallons of mixed NGL/MI @ 3.26 lbs/ gal and 75% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 35,500 lbs.
-	The 42-1362 & 42-1379 Depropanizer Feed Preheater Exchangers (two units total) with NGL/MI present on the tube side of the exchanger each have an available tube side volume of 76 gallons NGL/MI @ 3.26 lbs/gal and 75% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 190 lbs each.
-	The 42-1102 Depropanizer Tower has a working liquid volume of 7,700 gallons NGL/MI @ 3.26 lbs/gallon and 75% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 19,000lbs.
-	The 42-1345 Depropanizer Overhead Condenser has a working liquid volume of 6 gallons NGL/MI @ 3.26 lbs/gallon and 75% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 15 lbs.
-	The 42-1238 Depropanizer Reflex Drum has a high liquid level of 900 gallons NGL/MI @ 3.26 lbs/gallon and 75% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 2,200 lbs.
-	The 42-1259 Depropanizer Off Gas Compressor Suction Scrubber has a high liquid level of 170 gallons NGL @ 5.35 lbs/gallon and 55% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 400 lbs.
Total NGL/MI inventory onsite is approximately 76,000 lbs.

Catastrophic loss of NGL inventory from the 42-1253 Depropanizer Economizer Drum is the basis for the Worst Case Scenario calculations as it can have up to 35,500 lbs. The model used was RMPComp.

Other Information Required Per 40 CFR 68.155:
LPCAs accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are predicated on compliance with OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps include process hazard analysis (PHA). The facility has had no accidents in the past five years from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, p

roperty damage, or environmental damage. The emergency response program was developed consistent with OSHAs Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) and PSM standards, as well as other applicable regulations. Planned changes to improve safety occur through the incident investigation process, closure of PHA recommendations, and regularly scheduled safety meetings. 

Enclosed modules which house process equipment operated at LPC are equipped with fire suppression systems. In the event of fire, HalonA1 fire suppressant is automatically released to inhibit the chemical reaction of combustion and extinguish the flames. 

Prudhoe Bay has its own professionally-trained fire department which responds and serves as the local fire department. There is no other jurisdiction providing emergency response at LPC, with the exception of mutual aid provided by the fire departments of other nearby North-Slope Alaska oil fields.
